schema_place.name: Bondcliff
schema_place.description: Bondcliff is a 4,265 foot peak in New Hampshire offering hiking trails with scenic views.

mainEntity.name: How long does it take to hike Bondcliff?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most routes on Bondcliff take 8-10 hours round trip. The most popular trail is 17.8 miles with Hard difficulty. Start early, especially on weekends when parking fills quickly.
Bondcliff is rated Hard. At 4,265 feet, expect challenging terrain above treeline with potential for rapid weather changes. Proper footwear and preparation are essential.

mainEntity.name: Do I need a permit to hike Bondcliff?

acceptedAnswer.text: No hiking permit is required for Bondcliff. However, parking fees may apply at trailheads (typically $3-5/day for WMNF or state parks). A WMNF parking pass covers most White Mountain trailheads.

mainEntity.name: What is the best trail to hike Bondcliff?

acceptedAnswer.text: The most popular route is the Lincoln Woods to Bondcliff, offering Classic route to one of NH's most iconic viewpoints..

mainEntity.name: When is the best time to hike Bondcliff?

acceptedAnswer.text: The best hiking season for Bondcliff is late May through October. Summer and fall offer the best conditions, though expect crowds on weekends. Winter hiking requires specialized gear and experience.

page_content.description:
At 4,265 feet, Bondcliff ranks among New Hampshire's celebrated 4000-Footers—a collection of 48 peaks that challenge and inspire hikers throughout the Northeast. This hard summit offers a quintessential White Mountain experience.

Popular Routes

The most popular route, **Lincoln Woods to Bondcliff**, covers 17.8 miles and is rated Hard. Classic route to one of NH's most iconic viewpoints.

Peak Bagging

**Extend Your Adventure:** West Bond lies just 1.0 miles away, making it an excellent addition for ambitious hikers looking to bag multiple summits.

spring.title: Spring Conditions
spring.conditions: Muddy trails, snow above 3000ft until May
spring.tips: Trail closures for mud season (April-May). Check conditions before heading out.

summer.title: Summer Conditions
summer.tips: Start early to avoid afternoon storms and parking issues. Peak crowds on weekends.

fall.title: Fall Conditions
fall.conditions: Peak foliage late Sept, early snow possible in October
fall.tips: Peak foliage brings peak crowds. Weekday hikes recommended. Watch for ice above treeline in late October.

winter.title: Winter Conditions
winter.conditions: Full winter conditions, extreme cold and wind above treeline
winter.tips: Winter hiking requires specialized skills and gear. Never hike alone. Check avalanche conditions for steeper terrain.

current_hazards: ⚠️ ALPINE ZONE: Weather changes rapidly. Turn back if conditions deteriorate.
Winter conditions in effect - full mountaineering gear required
Hypothermia risk - temperatures 20-40°F colder at summit
Trail markers may be buried under snow
